segments.text: You mentioned that you were mayor of Amarillo for a period of six years.
Could you tell me a little bit about that?
I was first city commissioner for six years, and then I was mayor for six years during the war.
And it was during this time that you were also in your brick supply business.
Oh yeah, that's not a full-time job.
without practicing no remuneration.
The city managed the form of government.
Of course, it took a lot of time.
Well, I gather you have a city council and a mayor, and the city council meets how often?
Once a week.
Once a week then.
Were there any particular things which were accomplished for Amarillo while you were mayor?
Yes, they moved in there.
There was a mechanic school around here, and the city had a whole lot to do with that.
It had 20, 30,000 men out there at the air base.
Now this mechanic school, is that a military?
Aviation mechanic school.
This is for the Air Force?
At that time, I guess, was it still the Army Air Corps at that point, or had it been a separate branch by then?
It was a separate branch.
So did the city make a proposal to the government to establish it here?
Oh, yeah.
I made a trip every month to Washington for six months before we ever got a vote.
We were working with the Chamber of Commerce.
and did you work with your congressman in Washington too or?
Oh yeah.
Were there any say any plans made for future development of Amarillo or anything like that while you were serving as mayor?
Oh yes, we had a portion for a plan
And I remember still doing good.
Well, it's certainly, from what I've seen of it, a fairly well laid out city and looks to be quite prosperous.
Yes, we had a slump here after they closed the base, but it's come back nice and strong.
When was the base closed?
It was reopened in 52 and closed in about 58.
That was during the Korean War that was reopened.
So you would have had a slump then say after 58 when it was closed?
Yes, we had a slump there after it was closed in 47.
What's the base being used for now?
There's a school out there, Texas Technical School.
And then there's some private industries moved in out there.
Different companies.
Are there any other, say, accomplishments that you would like to be remembered for?
No, I don't think so.
You don't think so?
The two boys, you ready?
Okay.
